summary: This research investigates the genetic diversity and historical distribution of the creosote bush (Larrea tridentata), a prominent shrub in North America's warm deserts. It examines both ancient and modern ploidy levels, revealing that ancient creosote remains were exclusively diploid, while modern plants predominantly exhibit diploidy, with tetraploids found only at northern sites. The study also notes that the larger guard cell areas in modern diploid plants may be adaptations to increasing aridity. The findings suggest that tetraploids may have recently expanded into eastern regions, paralleling the late arrivals of other desert plants.
